head.title: Bush Drops Plans to Resubmit 3 Judicial Nominees

hedline.hl1: Bush Drops Plans to Resubmit 3 Judicial Nominees
hedline.hl2: Bush Drops Plans to Renominate 3 Judges

body.head.byline: By NEIL A. LEWIS; Stephen Labaton contributed reporting.

abstract.p: Pres Bush drops plans to nominate three federal appeals courts candidates who have been vigorously opposed by Senate Democrats; William J Haynes II, William Myers III and Terrence Boyle are withdrawn as judicial nominees in move widely seen as Bush concession to political reality; photos (M)

block.p: In an apparent effort to lower the temperature in the fierce battle over federal judges -- and in a concession to political reality -- President Bush said Tuesday that he was dropping plans to nominate three of his choices for the federal appeals courts who have been vigorously opposed by Senate Democrats.

The White House announced that the three candidates, all conservatives, had themselves asked for their names to be withdrawn. But the announcement was widely taken to mean that the president had decided that renominating them would be a needlessly provocative act, one that would anger Democrats without sufficient political payoff from conservatives for sticking by the nominees.

In an apparent effort to lower the temperature in the fierce battle over federal judges -- and in a concession to political reality -- President Bush said Tuesday that he was dropping plans to nominate three of his choices for the federal appeals courts who have been vigorously opposed by Senate Democrats.

The White House announced that the three candidates, all conservatives, had themselves asked for their names to be withdrawn. But the announcement was widely taken to mean that the president had decided that renominating them would be a needlessly provocative act, one that would anger Democrats without sufficient political payoff from conservatives for sticking by the nominees.

Days after the November election that gave the Democrats control of Congress, Mr. Bush pledged to renominate the three. His words prompted denunciations from Democrats that he had not taken any lessons from the election and that he was not, as he had claimed, prepared to engage them in a bipartisan way.

Democrats were able to block the confirmations of the three -- William J. Haynes II, William Myers III and Terrence Boyle -- in the last Congress. With the Democrats now in control of the Senate, the three's chances to be confirmed were reduced further.
After Tuesday's announcement, some Democrats expressed appreciation for the decision.

''It's the first whiff of conciliation we've had on the issue of judges,'' said Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York and a Judiciary Committee member who has been vocal in his complaints that Mr. Bush has sought confrontation on the issue of judges.
''The election demanded much more bipartisanship than they've been giving,'' Mr. Schumer said. ''But this might be the beginning of a path we can walk down together.''

Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, the Democrat who formally assumes the chairmanship of the Judiciary Committee this week, praised Mr. Bush for not resubmitting the three nominees. ''This new Congress presents an opportunity for a fresh start on judicial nominations, one that emphasizes qualifications and bipartisan consensus over game-playing,'' Mr. Leahy said.
In addition to the three, a fourth federal appeals court nominee who had been opposed by the Democrats, Michael J. Wallace of Mississippi, withdrew last month.
Democrats had vowed to block the confirmations of all four.

Mr. Haynes, who was nominated to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, has been the Pentagon's general counsel and was deeply involved in setting the administration's interrogation and detention policies. Mr. Haynes wrote or supervised memorandums that secretly authorized harsh treatment for detainees at Guant√°namo Bay, Cuba, and Iraq.

Mr. Myers had been nominated for a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The circuit, based in San Francisco, covers nine states and is frequently at the center of disputes over environmental laws and regulations. He was strongly opposed by many environmental groups for his history as a lobbyist for mining and ranching interests and speeches criticizing restrictions on those groups.

Judge Boyle, a district court judge in North Carolina, drew opposition to his nomination to the Fourth Circuit from Democrats and liberal groups for his rulings in civil rights cases. Mr. Wallace, nominated to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, was rated unqualified for the court by the American Bar Association.

At least one nominee had told friends he was interested in withdrawing long ago but agreed to keep his name in to satisfy the White House if the president wanted to continue pressing the nominations. When Mr. Bush announced his intention in November to renominate the four, political supporters said it was to keep in place the groundwork for an argument that the Democrats were obstructionist over judges.
Mr. Bush's decision will probably disappoint conservatives who were eager to continue that argument, but on Tuesday, some said they understood the political realities.

Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, the chairman of the agency that supervises most government broadcasts abroad, also asked the White House to withdraw his nomination for another term as chairman of the Broadcasting Board of Governors.

Mr. Tomlinson had also headed the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, but was forced to step down from that organization after an inspector general's report in 2005 found evidence that he had violated rules meant to insulate public television and radio from political influence.
